Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZGEN2215 - Law, Force and Legitimacy","description":"

The course will provide a foundational introduction to international law, an overview ofinternational humanitarian law, and the legal obligations that these bodies of law impose on states and armed forces prior to and during conflict. Beginning with a survey of the laws governing territorial disputes and the use of force, the course reviews the historical development of international humanitarian law, its key obligations, and the debate surrounding its creation. It then surveys a series of related ethical, legal and operational challenges raised by new forms of conflict and military operations including counterinsurgency and counter-terrorism, stability and reconstruction operations, humanitarian interventions and complex emergencies, conventional war-fighting, and air operations. Rather than narrowly treating ethical issues in terms of legal obligations, it explores how ethical questions have become central to strategic success.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7b8845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"International Law Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Two 40 minute online test to assess foundational understanding topics covered in Module 1 (the UN Charter, legal instruments, territorial disputes and use of force justifications).

Group feedback will be provided in the lectures and tutorials.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"338845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7f8845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a78845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a96199d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"178845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a961986","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"EPortfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Write a 500-800 word commentary on each of the three Modules.

Module 1 – Answer a set question on one of the following: 

  1. Reform of Article 51, 
  2. Chapter VII of the UN Charter 
  3. UN Resolution 1441 (2002) or, 
  4. The South China Sea dispute

Module 2: Choose one: 

  1. Write Peer reviews on three IHL Presentations (add comments to VoiceThread and also submit the text in TurnitIn) or, 
  2. Write an applied case study illustrating the operational challenges of one customary rule of IHL.

Module 3: Critically analyse the strategic and political legitimacy debates relating to one of the following: 

  1. Occupation. 
  2. Civilian casualties. 
  3. Counter insurgency or, 
  4. New Technologies
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"338845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7f8845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a78845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a96199d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f38845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5f8845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a96198a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"IHL Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This is a group exercise

Using VoiceThread, prepare a 10 Minute slide presentation (plus speaking notes) on an IHL Rule of War.  Drawing upon the ICRC Customary Law database and independent research, the presentation will explore the application of a rule of war in an operational context.

Guidelines (and worked example) for this task are available.

Formative feedback will be provided by tutor and summative feedback will be provided on TurnitIn.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"338845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7f8845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f38845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a78845f7db791c50eb6b147a3a96198f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial Engagement","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Evaluation of tutorial engagement in video conferencing (Collaborate) sessions. Attend and participate in the online tutorials. This assessment will be measured across four elements (PLAQ).

The Moodle forum will be used in cases where students have legitimate reasons for not being able to attend a live session and wish to make an asynchronous contribution. 

Attendance will be recorded on Moodle providing a dynamic report which is viewable by students.  Students will receive formative feedback by week 6. Students will receive summative feedback in Week 13.

CRITERIA (PLAQ)

Preparation

  • PASS: Regularly reads most prescribed tutorial readings.
  • HD:     Regularly reads all prescribed tutorial and some additional readings.

Listening to others

  • PASS: Treats others with courtesy and shows respect for their ideas. 
  • HD:      Demonstrates active listening. Acknowledges and builds from others’ contributions.

Attendance 

  • PASS: Absent from a maximum of 3 tutorials. 
  • HD:     Attends all tutorials.

Quality of contribution

  • PASS: May require prompting. Willing to express own ideas and opinions, provides relevant examples from course readings.
  • HD:     Without promoting, expresses well-thought out ideas and opinions and backs up with reference to course readings.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZGEN2222 - Introduction to Strategic Studies","description":"

Strategy may be defined as the means by which states and other organised groups use force or the threat of force to obtain their objectives. This course introduces students to the main concepts underlying this definition at the theoretical level and by the use of practical examples. Varieties of strategy, conventional armed forces, guerrilla forces and terror to achieve aims will be discussed. The place of Australia in the world will be a reference point. The course will also explore the determinants of land, naval, and air strategies and how these strategies have been integrated by various powers over the last century.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZGEN2240 - Introduction to Military Ethics","description":"

A changing military environment and developments in wider society combine to make new and increasingly complex ethical demands on Australian Defence Force officers. This course introduces students to ethical theory and debate, develops skills in applying ethics, and analyses various forms of ethical discourse. In order to maintain a practical approach, case studies will be used to introduce the problems to be examined in the course. Studying ethics may not make you a better person, but it will encourage self-awareness, clarity, and ability to engage in ethical dialogue with others inside and outside the military.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZGEN2801 - Strategy, Management and Leadership","description":"

This General Education course explores the ways that organisations set their strategic objectives (strategy), organise themselves to achieve those objectives (management) and secure the willing support of people who can affect mission accomplishment (leadership). During their careers, ADF officers can expect to play important roles in the management of Defence, but they will also have to interact with business firms, governments and volunteer organisations. This course prepares them for doing so by developing a broad understanding of strategy, management and leadership in organisations. In the last decade, Defence has become much more focused on coherent strategic management. Future ADF officers need to understand how strategic management concepts apply to Defence. They will also face the challenges of leading change within Defence. This course helps prepare students to take up those challenges.
